name: Greed Corp
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows® XP (SP3), Windows Vista® (SP1), Windows 7® Processor: Pentium 4 3GHz or comparable Memory: 1 GB Graphics: DirectX® 9-compatible graphics adapter with 128 MB RAM (ATI® X700 or better / NVIDIA GeForce® 6100 or better) DirectX®: DirectX®9.0c Hard Drive: 1 GB free space Sound: DirectX®9.0c-compatible

reviews.review_text: This a small TBS worth due to it's simplicity and effectiveness in its mechanics. It is a Risk styled game, where you control a faction that must destrtoy all enemy factions in a hexagonal tile base map. In order to do thta, players must generate income, done so by placing Harvesters accross the field; the important bit here is that harvesters generate income by smashing the tile where it was placed, in addition to all adjacent tiles; every time a tile is smashed, it lowers it's height, reaching a point where the tile fractures and subsequently collapses - what this means is that, as income is generated, the battlefield gets eventually destroyed, and by the end game, its rather common that only a couple of tiles remain in the whole battlefield.  The game is entirely deterministic - no dice is rolled at all. A duel is resoleved by the size of the attacking force, with the casualties determined by simple substraction (invading force unit count - defending force unit count). Addionally, all maps are perfectly symmetrical. This leaves the game's conflict to be entirely resolved by player's strategy and nothing else. This is easier said than done, however, as the tile destruction inflicted by harvesters (and player-deployed artillery) constantly change the battlefield, your strategy is in an ever constant need for change.  The game lacks a bit of variety, so it can easily become a little repetitive - this is not Chess nor Go in regards to depth. An expande sequel would have been indeed welcome, but this never came to pass. I still recommend it heartily if you are a fan of TBS.
Simple strategic fun. Easy to pick up, making it a good game to play with friends on the fly.

Greed Corp gives a unique way of planning out a TBS. While you naturally want large forces, the production of forces comes directly from destroying the ground beneath your own feet. This turns an otherwise aesthetically pleasing but unoriginal game into a very compelling game, and also opens may types of attacks and force build ups. As an added bonus, it's (or sometimes is) a very cheap game to buy, giving hours of enjoyment in medium sized battles for pennies on the dollar.

Interesting idea, but it gets old pretty quickly. Needed more concepts/variety.

Simple mechanics, not so simple strategies. While the single player campaign is rather easy, multiplayer is where this game shines. It's very easy for the game to turn from what appears to be an obvious win for one player into a complete disaster for that same player. A strategy that works once likely won't fool the same opponent(s) twice, so mixing it up is a must.

Too sloooooooow, could have been more fun is I hadn't have to wait 10 seconds for each action. Also, the controls seem a little uncomfortable, made mistakes several times.
It's a good strategy game with local multiplayer... but no controller support?

Extremely simple yet amazingly satisfying. A simple little strategy game that has an interesting twist. Has multiplayer and the atmosphere to the game is really cool. Nothing like destroying the land right under your enemy while listening to smooth jazz. I just wish the game was more deep and had more content because they could have taken this game far.
Its an amazing little game for an amazing little price, well worth the Moneys in my opinion. Has a few minor hiccups but overall Great Game. 9/10

War leaves nothing. Even the triumph doesn't leave you anything. Our effort to survive will eventually take everything we have. But we have to keep this war.  Most of all, the 'crucial' harvest mechanic inspired by 'the industrial revolutions and their destructive effects on the environment' is quite impressive. Seeing still working harvester fading off under the clouds with the fragments of the land just collapsed by the destructive effect of the harvester itself hurts somewhere inside of me every time.
Fun and quite tactical. Nice way to put in those boring times.
Fun with friends, a game we commonly go back to, decent strategy

A surprisingly complex simple little game where you build and conquer in a grid based world and wrecks it. Not much is left after you and the other warring companies are done.  The Multiplayer player base is unfortunately rarely very much alive, bring a few friends with you and this is awesome.
Strategy fun factor 10/10 ... i rarely play a game from beginning till the end. But in this one i reached the top of the mountain. if you like turn-based strategy don't miss this one.
Simple rules, deep strategy. Innovative multiparty multiplayer, any combination friend/online/AI. Dutch Developer! Dutch Developer! Did i say Dutch Developer?
Relaxing board game. Probably would be better played on a tablet.
Definitely a game worth buying. I got it out of a Humble Bundle, but definitely would pay full price for it now that I've played it.

A quirky, inventive strategy game that manages to stand out from the usual Strategy routine. Its simplicity and streamlined mechanics are akin to Chess, which is simultaneously what appeals and limits it. The nature of a constantly disintegrating game world is a powerful image that makes the game one you'll remember.

The core idea is interesting, it really is as they advertise, that you have to choose a balance of hexes to operate on and harvest, but the game could use a slightly wider variety of approaches. If you look at a screenshot, the menu on the left with 8 buttons are literally all the possible actions. I havent played it much, but in my experience this far, games consist of an early game where you mine away most of the map as fast as you can, and then you just poke at each other from the remaining islands for the rest of the game. This has all been vs AI though, and the game may be different against a human player.  I really like the general idea, but at the same time there's some fundamental things I'd like to see different.
Simple to learn but harder to master. This is a fun little turn based game (I'm not usually a fan but I like this). Good to play vs your friends & play the single player campaign to unlock more maps!
A challenging yet fun game were thinking a few steps ahead is key. A bit like simplifided chess with explosions and a crumbling playing field that you are taking right out from under your own feet!

Fun little tactical game that has a fast pace. Think of chess but with resource collection, cannons, airships, and collapsing game boards! Great game to jump in and out of for some enjoyable thinking based entertainment.
Pure strategy; great game mechanics; very fitting theme - go buy this game.
Great strategy game, with many surprising tactitcs. It's like a cool board game...

Pretty neat game. Menu/gound/graphics/mechanics feel solid. Although it lacks in complexity and requires little strategy. So to say, a childish game. Also had trouble getting it to run on an eyefinity system at first. In the end I had to find out it's a console game..
This game is awesome and could use all the players it can get!
Incredibly fun turn based strategy game. Excellent game to play with a friend. Cheap.

This is a very well done and put together game. It is simple enough for anyone to get into, but challenging enough for even the most seasoned strategy gamers. To put it in short, its foundation is like that of the game of chess, but more creative in the fact that the king cannot hide on the back of the board least he risk plummeting to his death as the ground crumbles around him.
It's a fun game...but honestly the third level (Turbo Tunnel) of Battletoads is easier than the third level of Greed Corp.  Be prepared to be beaten...by 'Beginner' level A.I. players.
